Entry.2: attended by natives. From the dump @ Ramleh we motored over the dusty & bumpy road to Jaffa. Jaffa is much modernised & has lost most of its attraction, I was much interested however in the landing of railway materials which is at present going on. The cargo vessels lie out to sea & the staffare ferried in by Surfboats. The port is extremely treacherous as the boats have to pass through a narrow waterway between the rocks of Andromede, & even when inside the reefs there is barely enough water in which to swing them. Jan 21st
Left Dieran at 7 am in a ford car for Jerusalem. With a 
fine
 beautiful morning favouring, we had a fine through bumpy run to Latron which is at the foot of the hills & we began the assent of the foothills along the road to Jerusalem. After a four hours run through mountanious country we arrived @ the old city of Jerusalem. The Jerusalem of today cannot be termed a typical oriental city, inside its walls its Eastern character has been generally preserved but in recent years European influence has been great.Without the walls a new town has grown. Jan 16th
Went to Zernukah a native village a few miles from Dieran beautiful weather favoured an enjoyable trip made a trifle exciting by the Ford C-- getting stuck in the mud. We requisitioned the energies of some passing bedouins & soon got on the road again. Zernukah like many other similar villages is built on a hill slope its approaches being hedged by fine avenues of Cactus. The sheik gave us all assistance possible & all the rest of the indolent ragged population & the ever accompanying crowd of small boys joined in. Cpt H. had the 2nd Regt. paraded throughthe

Jan 15th
Remained at Dieran helping Cpt H develop the results being very good.

Beautiful mild weather with blue sky making Dieran more beautiful than it is. The little red tiled houses nestling amidst the green gum trees is just like
home
& how I long to be their once again.

Jan 13th
The rain came down in torrents all night & has continued to day accompanied by heavy lightening. The Bdge in Bivouacs (Bivvys) were washed out & are having a miserble time. We are now attached to desert Coys again.

Jan 9th
Went across to the beach @ the Wady Nahr Sukereir where a vessal is being discharged, the beach was teeming with natives engaged in the work & was one of the most animated & noisy sceens I have witnessed here.

The vessal lay out about Â½ mile& a large number of small craft were ferrying the cargo ashore.

When the bows grounded a line was hooked on & about 100 natives hauled the craft inshore. Imense dumps were formed which were being transported by thousands of camels.

We returned across the sand hills in the late evening the desert being

several weeks are all in fine fettle. The riding was admirable & all seemed to enjoy the exercise & turnout. The immediate neighbourhood is the centre of a number of camps,so that the sand hills are always a bustle with horses & men & the unending streams of accompanying camel tports. Our Hdqs have their tents pitched in what was once an old figgery & isolated from the other camping, what astonishes one is the great size of the fig trees & the density of their growth more so as their owners apparently pay little or no attention to pruning or firtilising.

Entry.6: Wild stormy night with Tropical deluge, conditions moderated considerably during the day & only occasional showers fell. Capt Hurley & myself went out after mud pictures in which the country is at present swimming. The great field in front ofEsdud Station was submerged about four feet & with it valuable supplys of fodder & rations. A great string of over 2000 camels had to pass over it & Ipitied the wretched creatures & their destitue drivers to see these fine beasts of the burning desert wallowing in the mud of Palestine winter, is pitiful indeed & their drivers with hardly any suitable clothing or protection from the fierce weather, it is no wonder that they perishin larg numbers. Entry.7:
The rain which has been theatening much of late came down in heavey downpour during the night & has continued without cessation all day. Heavy winds also accompany it so we just had to stay in our bivouac & tell yarns, the yarns bythe way were mostly told by Capt Hurley conserning his trip to the South P. & it was very interesting to listen to him. The big flat where we had the unpleasant experience of being
washed
flooded out on Xmas day is again awash & the roads impassable. The wadies have been running bankers & Tport is more or less disorganised. Thank heaven it is dry in our tent for Ilook across a dismal expance of mud where the Horse Tport & Camels are having a miserable time.
